ILLEGAL ALIENS: IMPACT IN CITY IS UNCERTAIN

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 2009 words


Most of the illegal aliens in New York City have jobs and earn as much as legal
aliens, and most pay Social Security taxes and some income taxes, according to
many immigration specialists.

Researchers also believe that the presence of a vast illegal population in New
York tends to keep wages low and working conditions poor and that many illegal
aliens have successfully and fraudulently enrolled in public-assistance
programs.

As a result, the role of illegal aliens in the city's economy is a mixture of
often-conflicting benefits and drains that has defied systematic analysis by
economists and immigration experts.

Most government agencies, sensitive to charges of discrimination, are reluctant
to single out particular ethnic and racial groups and, therefore, data based on
national origins or even places of birth is not readily available.

'A Child Is a Child'


The Board of Education, probably the agency most used by illegal aliens, asks
for birth certificates only as proof of a child's age. The board gets state aid
for illegal aliens, as it does for all students.

''A child is a child, and we don't investigate whether he is here illegally or
not,'' a board spokesman, Gloria Lesser, said. ''It's not an issue.''

A four-year-old suit by the city and state against the Census Bureau contends
that minority groups, including illegal aliens, were undercounted in the 1980
Census, depriving the city and state of a rightful share of Congressional
representation and Federal revenue sharing. A decision is expected in Federal
court by the end of the year.

There is no agreement on the number of illegal aliens in the city. There are
200,000 according to one analysis of the 1980 Census, 500,000 according to many
academicians and the New York district office of the Immigration and
Naturalization Service, and 750,000 according to the City Planning Commission.

The Census Bureau has said that if there was undercounting, at least $9.40 in
revenue sharing would be lost for each person not counted. The city and state
argue that the estimate should be more than doubled.

Loss of $2.8 Million a Year

Even if the immigration service estimate is correct and the city's is too high,
an undercounting of 300,000 would mean that New York is losing a minimum of $2.8
million a year in revenue sharing.

To help identify trends among all foreign- born people in New York - legal as
well as illegal - the Planning Commission began a study a year ago that it
expects to complete next year.

A Planning Commission memo last March on the status of the study highlights the
difficulties of the task.

''City agencies do not seem to have standardized policies about reporting
illegals to the I.N.S., and there is no consistency in how these issues are
handled,'' it said. ''Similarly, the I.N.S. has no hard and fast policy on the
types of cases it will prosecute and those it will ignore.''

Last July, Mayor Koch created an Office of Immigrant Affairs at the Planning
Commission to complete the study and coordinate services for immigrants. The
head of the office, Elizabeth Bogen, said: ''There's been a laissez-faire
attitude to studying illegal aliens, because people in the power structure tend
to believe they don't cause much of a problem and because the issue is such a
political hot potato that discussing it would cause more harm than good. That's
why we've decided to study the impact of all aliens, without getting hung up on
the issue of illegals per se.''

Despite the absence of a comprehensive survey, several conclusions about the
cost-benefit ratio of illegal aliens can be made, according to immigration
specialists.

Comparison With Other Workers


A recent Gallup poll found that most Americans believed illegal aliens ended up
on welfare and raised tax burdens. That view is disputed by almost all
immigration specialists, who say most illegal aliens have jobs.

A study by New York University in 1981 on immigrants from the Dominican Republic
in three city neighborhoods found that almost all legal and illegal immigrants
worked and that they found jobs within a week after they started to look for
them.

The study also found that there was almost no difference in job experience or
income levels of aliens based on legal status and that most aliens earned at
least the minimum wage.

''Illegals are generally working people, and the notion that they cost society a
great deal is a myth,'' said Glauco Perez, a Ph.D. candidate in political
science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and executive assistant for
policy and program development at the New York City Human Resources
Adminstration.

Wages in Restaurants


Other academics say that well over half the illegal population pays Social
Security and Federal, state and local income taxes. They say that although
illegal aliens are helping to pay for Social Security, most will never receive
the benefits.

A study this year by Thomas Bailey, a research associate at Columbia University,
based on interviews with 90 New York restaurant owners and managers, found
legality made little difference in what immigrant restaurant workers were paid,
although they were ''willing to take restaurant work at wages well below those
that would be acceptable to large numbers of native- born adult male blacks.''

Some economists say that low wages keep labor costs and retail prices down,
which in turn allow industries facing severe competition to survive. They say
that without low-wage immigrant labor, the garment industry, for example, would
have to move many of its operations overseas to remain competitive, and dozens
of ethnic restaurants would have to go out of business.

Because illegal aliens are willing to work hard and not complain, the economists
said, they tend to be a favored work force in a number of industries.

'Willingness to Work'


In a study of Southern California in the 1970's, Thomas Muller, an economist
with the Urban Institute, a nonprofit research organization in Washington that
studies social and political issues, found that employers preferred undocumented
workers for their ''willingness to work under poorer conditions to those
acceptable to most Americans, low absenteeism and solid work habits.''

It is generally accepted that illegal aliens have to work more for less,
especially if their employers are aware of their illegal status.

''I have a good boss, I work hard, I don't complain and I don't have any
problems,'' said a 23-year-old Salvadoran man who packs vegetables for the
minimum wage, $3.35 an hour, in Brooklyn.

Many illegal aliens function just like citizens - not only working and paying
taxes, but also getting promotions.

One 26-year-old woman from India, who arrived here in 1979 and paid an American
man $3,000 to marry her, has been living in the United States illegally ever
since the Immigration Service discovered her fraudulent marriage.

She has used a valid Social Security card - issued to her only for the purpose
of opening a bank account - to get a variety of jobs, including a clerk in a
jewelry store, a laundry worker, a dishwasher in a bakery and a counter person
at McDonald's and Burger King. Some of her employers paid her as little as $2 an
hour. Many aliens misuse their cards in this way.

'Grateful for America'


She now does word processing at a New York brokerage concern for $16,000 a year.

''Every year I file my tax return, just like everyone else,'' she said. ''I'm
grateful for America, for giving me the chance to stand on my own two feet.''

She used her own name, Social Security number and her file number for an
application for permanent residence status that she received when she and her
husband were first interviewed by the Immigration Service. Neither the
Immigration Service nor the I.R.S. has made cases like hers a top priority. No
effort is now being made to deport her.

Illegal aliens cannot avoid sales taxes or indirect property taxes, such as
those figured in rental charges. But many are paid their salaries in cash ''off
the books'' and never pay income tax.  ''Living in New York takes big money,''
said a 32-year-old South Korean graduate student, who cannot legally work on his
student visa. He supplements money he receives from his family by working at an
Oriental publication for $4 an hour in cash.

''I feel guilty working and not paying taxes, but morally I have the right to
exist and work while I'm studying in New York,'' he said.

Illegal aliens are ineligible for public assistance programs, and only sketchy
estimates of their fraudulent use exist.

Effect on Assistance


In a study based on interviews with nearly 800 apprehended illegal aliens, David
S. North, a political scientist with the New TransCentury Foundation in
Washington, said that illegal aliens made substantial but below- average use of
tax-supported programs and that legal immigrants made average use of them.

It is somewhat easier for illegal aliens to receive unemployment benefits than
public assistance. Most workers whose employers pay them legally are covered by
unemployment insurance, and many aliens belong to unions that help them in
applying for unemployment.

Illegal aliens have the greatest impact on the health-care and education
systems. They try to avoid going to private doctors because of the expense and
tend to rely on public hospitals, particularly emergency and delivery rooms, for
care. The City Health and Hospitals Corporation estimates that unreimbursed
inpatient care of illegal aliens in New York costs $28 million a year.

''I try never to get sick,'' said the young woman from India. ''When I need
medical care, I ask a friend who's married to a doctor to get a prescription for
me.''

Competition for Resources


Voluntary agencies said there was little they could do to help aliens. ''Once in
a while, we can help with a doctor or even an operation, but there's nothing we
can do if the alien needs $400 a day inpatient hospital care,'' said the Rev.
Peter Zendzian of the Catholic Migration and Refugee Office of the Diocese of
Brooklyn.

A 1979 study by the Federal Labor Department that is often cited by the
Immigration Service estimated that one in five jobs held by illegal aliens -
among a total of 1.2 million jobs - could be filled by unemployed Americans.

''Illegal aliens detract from the city because they are competing for jobs and
benefits and putting a drain on social services,'' said Lawrence Paretta,
assistant director for investigations of the Immigration Service's New York
office. ''I've never bought the argument that that no one else will do the work
- if the wages and conditions are good.''

In the last 10 months, through various investigations, the district office said,
it has saved more than $5 million in fraudulent unemployment, student loan,
Medicaid and public-housing payments.

To prevent social-service payments to illegal aliens, the Immigration Service
last year began Project SAVE - which stands for Systematic Alien Verification
for Entitlement - in Colorado, Illinois and California.

It is a cooperative, computerized effort between the Immigration Service, other
Federal organizations and state agencies. So far, the three states have sought
to uncover only unemployment fraud, by carefully checking all aliens applying
for aid to make sure they are eligible.

New York will be among the next five states to join the program.

When all 50 states are in the program, the Immigration Service predicts a
combined saving of $10.7 billion at the end of two years, an estimate that most
immigration researchers feel is too high.

Researchers also believe that as long as the economy is expanding and illegal
aliens can get jobs, undocumented workers will continue to pour into New York.

''This is our country's version of Europe's guest-worker policy,'' Mr. Muller
said. ''Not only the supply is here, but the demand, too.''

               October 28, 1984, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

ILLEGAL ALIENS DESCRIBE LIFE IN SOCIETY'S SHADOWS

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 26, Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 1172 words

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Oct. 27


To Hector and Maria, the major immigration bill that failed in Congress earlier
this month was of little concern because their arrival in the United States was
too recent to qualify them for its amnesty provisions.

Whatever Congress decided, they knew, they and their two children would have
only two choices: return to Mexico or continue a furtive, fearful existence.
Like some six million others in the United States, the latest working estimate,
they are ''undocumented'' aliens.

If illegal aliens were considered a minority group, they would be the
third-largest in the United States, behind black and Hispanic people.  But they
are officially invisible.

For perhaps three million of them, the immigration bill would have meant a new
life in the open and eventually, if all conditions were met, full citizenship.
But when Congress went home without approving the measure they faced, as before,
an indefinite future.

Unlike citizens, the ''undocumented'' have no papers to prove their identity, at
least none that are legitimate. They have no birth certificates, no resident
alien cards, no passports, no Social Security numbers. They usually have no
fixed address and no bank account. Many have no driver's license, no credit
card, no charge account and no medical record, not even names that are their
own.

The accounts that follow tell of real ''illegals,'' but because their lives are
clouded by the fear of apprehension and deportation, they have sometimes used
names they chose to match their fraudulent papers.



Hector became an illegal alien in March 1981, when he was 29 years old. He
slipped across the border at Laredo and paid smugglers $350 to take him to
Houston. Hector and 84 others made the trip in a horse van.

Several months later he paid $850 to have Maria and their children, then 4 and 8
years old, join him. Since then they have made a shaky but better life for
themselves, living in a rented house trailer, paying $225 a month, and equipping
it with a color television set and other appliances.

Hector earns $4.12 an hour as a church janitor and is looking for a second job
as a painter. Maria earns $30 a day as a maid.

This spring Hector returned to Mexico for his mother's funeral. His
mother-in-law came back with him, floating in an inner tube as he swam the Rio
Grande. They paid smugglers $1,000 to take them to Houston. Hector borrowed the
money from friends and is still repaying it.

Despite the problems of living in secret, Hector and Maria say their life here
is a world apart from the unrelenting poverty they knew in Mexico, where bare
necessities often seemed a luxury and there was often too little to eat.

''When we were living there,'' said Hector, ''sometimes my kids' shoes, they are
awful. I have to save before I can buy some new shoes for them. Now, when they
say they need shoes, I say, 'O.K., let's go buy them.' ''

Because of the fear of deportation, Hector has often been exploited by
employers, working 90-hour weeks for $225 as a trash collector for a private
company. He also avoids places where other Hispanic people congregate for fear
of an immigration raid. He tells friends he is an American citizen from
California.

For some time he hoped that would become the truth. Now he knows is impossible,
at least for some time.

His only hope, he admits, is to lie, to find fraudulent documents saying he is a
legal resident.

''For my children to go to college here,'' he said in halting English, ''I will
try all ways to be legal.''



Sierra Lopez, who slipped across the border and came to Houston eight years ago,
when he was 16, had high hopes for the bill sponsored by Senator Alan K. Simpson
and Representative Romano L. Mazzoli, which would probably have offered him
temporary legal status and an eventual chance for citizenship.

Mr. Lopez, who is knowledgeable, was not concerned about the bill's requirement
that, to become a citizen, he would have to demonstrate that he was proficient
in English or was learning it and had or was acquiring a fundamental
understanding of American history and government.

He is fiercely eager for special training.

Mr. Lopez, who had worked as a construction laborer, has been blind since
February 1980, when two men in a passing car, possibly because of some perceived
affront in traffic, fired several shots at an automobile in which he was riding.
One of the bullets hit Mr. Lopez in the right eye and severed an optic nerve,
blinding him.

Since then he has sought help in vain, living with the assistance of charties
and church groups.

''The thing I want most is job training,'' he said. But because he acknowledges
he was an illegal alien, he has been refused admission to publicly financed
programs for the blind. Under the provisions of the Simpson-Mazzoli bill, he
would probably have qualified for vocational training.

But even without such help, he said, ''I can't return to Mexico.'' ''A sighted
person can't make it,'' he said. ''A blind person is considered as a piece of
meat to be sent into the streets begging.''



Phillipe, who is 25 years old and says he has lived in Houston for eight years,
expresses little fear of being apprehended and deported.''I can run,'' he says.
But he concedes he has had bad work experiences with employers because, as an
illegal worker, he has no channel to complain of abuses.

''They tell you they pay $3 an hour,'' he said. ''At the end of the week they
tell you, 'I'm only going to pay you $2 an hour. Take it if you want.' '' He
once worked a week for an employer who refused to pay him at all, he said.

Like many other illegal residents, Phillipe, who earns $3.50 an hour as a
painter, sends money to his family in Mexico, and he flies to Mexico City each
year to visit, recrossing the border on foot at Laredo or Brownsville.

Last year, he said, he sent only $300 home. ''My family needs money,'' he said,
''but you need money here, too.''



Jose, 30, is one of four illegal aliens cramped into a three-room apartment in
North Houston. The rent for the apartment, one of four in an old two- story
house, is $60 a week. Three of the men work as housepainters, and the fourth is
looking for a job. None speak English.

Jose, a painter, makes $7 an hour and says his life here is good.

Through an interpreter, Jose said he had been in this country eight years,
entering on a student visa to study electronics. When the visa expired, he
stayed on.

Jose said he would like legal status but hopes someday to return to Mexico,
which he regards as home. He sends $400 a month to his family there, but has
returned to Mexico only once, for a week.

Jose has no car and no driver's license. He has usually lived in rooms or
apartments provided by his employers, and he has no rent or utility receipts. He
does have some hospital bills, he remembers, because he was badly beaten shortly
after he arrived, and employment insurance paid for his treatment. Beyond that,
his past is invisible.

              January 23, 1985, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

CHURCH MEMBERS WILL PRESS SANCTUARY MOVEMENT

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING

SECTION: Section A; Page 24, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 752 words

DATELINE: TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 22


The woman, who is in her 30's and has four young children, does not want to give
her name.

''I'll probably go to jail sooner or later,'' she said ''I just want it put off
as long as I can.''

As she talks, two of her children, the boy about 4 years old and the girl 3,
clatter through the door of the church sanctuary where she is talking of her
efforts to help illegal aliens she believes are political refugees, and she
scoops them into her arms and laughs.

''Part of the reason I do it is I'm a mother,'' she said ''and I would want
another mother to shelter my children from a war.''

The woman is one of about 200 church workers in Tucson and southern Arizona who
regularly transport Guatemalan and Salvadoran refugees across the Mexican border
into the United States, find them food and shelter, and hide them from the
immigration authorities, often in the churches themselves.

'Sanctuary for the Oppressed'

They make no secret of the fact that they help refugees. Outside the old,
mission-style Tucson Southside Presbyterian Church there is a sign that reads,
''Esta es el Sanctuario para los Oprimidos de Centro America'' (''This is the
sanctuary for the oppressed of Central America.'')

On Jan. 14, the Government announced that 16 people, including the pastor of
Southside Presbyterian, the Rev. John M. Fife; two Roman Catholic priests and
three nuns, had been indicted on 71 counts of conspiracy to smuggle illegal
aliens into the United States and related charges.

About 60 aliens named as co-conspirators but not indicted were arrested over the
next weekend, and the Government has also named some 25 other people, many of
them church lay workers who sheltered or transported the aliens, as additional
unindicted co-conspirators.

It is expected that some of these will be asked to testify. They could face the
possibility of jail sentences for contempt if they refused.

Despite the Government crackdown, many of those involved in transporting and
hiding the refugees say they will continue to do so. This Wednesday and Thursday
members of the Sanctuary movement are to meet in this city to discuss the
implications of the crackdown.

Brought Refugees to Tucson

The young mother, who was not among those indicted, said she had transported
Central American refugees ''a couple dozen times,'' from single men and women
traveling alone to as many as 11 people whom she said she had brought to Tucson
in a large van.

She said she had never brought anyone across the border herself, instead picking
them up on the American side.

''Just on this side,'' she explained. ''There are times when I was supposed to
bring people across, working with a priest or someone on the other side, but I
never had to.''

''I always travel with between one and four of my own children,'' she said.
''It's part of the camouflage.''

Although she said she was ''physically sick'' at the thought of going to jail -
the penalty for transporting illegal aliens is up to five years in prison for
each instance - she said she would ''definitely'' continue.

''Probably more than ever,'' she said, ''because a lot of people will be out of
commission in the near future because of the indictments.''

'Housewives, Elderly, Retirees'

''The main people who do the runs,'' those who actually smuggle and transport
the aliens once inside this country, ''are housewives, elderly people,
retirees,'' said Timothy Nonn, a seminary student who is one of the unindicted
co- conspirators.

Mr. Nonn is one of the organizers of the Tucson sanctuary movement, which has
spread to some 200 churches around the country and has been endorsed by major
church groups that include the Conference of the United Methodist Church and the
Peace Fellowship of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church.

In Tucson, 10 Protestant churches, three Roman Catholic churches and a Jewish
synagogue have signed a covenant of assistance to the sanctuary movement,
although only about a half- dozen have actually housed refugees on the church
premises.

''Some are asking volunteers to house refugees, provide food, funds, jobs,
spiritual support,'' said Mr. Nonn. In some congregations, refugees are actually
sheltered.

Very few refugees stay in Tucson, with most going to resettlement centers
elsewhere, he said.

''Los Angeles is a major area,'' he continued. ''They probably have over a
couple hundred thousand Central Americans there, and San Francisco has perhaps
60,000.''

THE NATION;
Friction BuildsOn Sanctuary

BYLINE: By Michael Wright, Katherine Roberts and Caroline Rand Herron

SECTION: Section 4; Page 2, Column 2; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 393 words


The Government's efforts to stop religious groups from smuggling Central
American refugees into the United States ran into an unsympathetic jury and a
group of hostile Lutheran bishops last week. Dozens of church workers and scores
of illegal immigrants joined to pledge that they would continue to run an
underground railroad into the Southwest.

While about 1,000 sanctuary workers and illegal aliens gathered in a synagogue
in Tucson, Ariz., to condemn United States policy in Guatemala and El Salvador,
a Roman Catholic lay worker, Jack Elder, went on trial in Texas on charges that
he had transported three Salvadorans 30 miles from a halfway house to a bus
station in violation of Federal immigration law. A jury in Corpus Christi took
less than two hours to decide that Mr. Elder's work did not further the illegal
journey of the undocumented aliens in this country. They did not rule on the
broader questions raised by Mr. Elder and others in the church-based sanctuary
movement that they have acted out of religious conviction to protect victims of
political persecution. It is the Government, the sanctuary workers claim, that
has violated the law by refusing to grant asylum to Central Americans fleeing
death squads and persecution.

When news of the verdict reached the synagogue in Tucson, the audience broke
into cheers and crying. A spokesman said it would have ''a tremendous impact''
on the movement and on the cases of 16 other sanctuary workers indicted earlier
this month, even though there is no legal connection between the Texas trial and
the Arizona cases.

In Washington bishops who head three major Lutheran organizations urged the
Government to end the ''prosecution and monitoring'' of ''this difficult moral
and theological issue.'' Of the 200 churches involved in the sanctuary movement
around the country, about 15 of them are Lutheran, according to church
officials.

The bishops' statement did not stop Federal officials from proceeding with their
effort to slow down the sanctuary movement. ''We have the laws of this country
to carry out,'' they said. Wednesday nine leaders of the movement appeared in
Federal court in Tucson to plead not guilty to charges of conspiring to smuggle
and harbor illegal aliens. They were released on their own recognizance and
vowed to ''continue to engage in sanctuary ministry.''

RULING ALLOWS CUBAN OUSTER

SECTION: Section 1; Page 9, Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 328 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1


Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist of the Supreme Court late today refused
to block the Federal Government's imminent deportation of a group of illegal
immigrants from Cuba being held in the Federal Penitentiary in Atlanta.

The Cubans, who arrived with refugees from the Cuban port of Mariel in 1980, are
scheduled to be deported starting Feb. 8 under an agreement between the United
States and Cuba that was announced late last year.

But the agreement was threatened by a decision by Judge Marvin Shoob of Federal
District Court in Atlanta, who ruled in October that the Cubans had the right to
new hearings in their efforts to obtain political asylum.

At the Government's request, the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th
Circuit issued a stay of Judge Shoob's decision last month.

Attorneys for the Cubans then asked the Supreme Court for a stay of the
appellate court's action, arguing that the Cubans would suffer ''irreparable
harm'' by being deported before their rights to asylum could be determined by
American courts.

The Justice Department opposed the request, arguing that it was ''essential to
this country's foreign policy interests'' to go forward with the deportation
agreement. That agreement also calls for the United States to resume normal
handling of immigrant visa applications from Cubans who want to come here.

In denying the Cubans' request today, Justice Rehnquist said that the Court of
Appeals had considered the questions carefully in permitting the deportations to
go forward on a limited basis. ''This Court is not in a position to second-guess
a balancing of this kind,'' he said.

The Court of Appeals is scheduled to hear further arguments in the case on Feb.
25. The Government plans to deport 100 to 150 Cubans a month, limiting
deportation to those who because of their criminal records would in any event
not qualify for political asylum. The deportation agreement applies to some
2,700 Cubans.

               November 18, 1984, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

JOBS SCARCE FOR PICKERS COMING BACK TO FLORIDA

SECTION: Section 1; Part 2; Page 50, Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 851 words

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 17


Thousands of migrant workers returning to Florida for the start of the annual
citrus harvest are finding few jobs and low wages because of the severe freeze
that killed millions of citrus trees last year.

The outbreaks of citrus canker in recent months have exacerbated the problems
for the workers, many of whom consider Florida home but do migrant work
elsewhere in other seasons. The plant disease destroyed thousands of trees in
nurseries where some of the fruit pickers had hoped to find jobs tending young
trees.

State employment officials preparing to aid those competing for scarce jobs say
that they expect growing problems in the next month or two and that the
situation may not ease for two or three years, when the damaged trees begin
bearing fruit again.

The freeze last December, the worst in this century, resulted in $1 billion in
losses after it killed or damaged millions of trees in 250,000 acres of groves
in the northern tier of the state's valuable citrus belt.

Coming Home for Season

State officials, growers and migrant leaders say many of those who work the
Florida groves spend their summers picking vegetables or fruit in the North or
in Texas. They return to the same areas of Florida, often to the same homes,
where they attend the local churches, enroll their children in the schools and
work nearby groves six to nine months of the year.

''I don't call them migrants,'' said Joel Phillips, executive director of the
Plymouth Citrus Growers Association. ''These are people who live here, are
citizens of central Florida. They may go North for a few months, but they're
citizens here.''

Last year's freeze forced Mr. Phillips's group to dissolve. It represented about
250 growers in Lake and Orange Counties and employed about 1,000 pickers.

Job Figures in Dispute

Estimates of the number of fruit pickers in Florida vary widely, but state
employment officials say about 27,000 people were picking fruit in the days just
after last year's freeze at Christmastime.

Benito Lopez, president of the 6,000- member United Migrants Association, based
in Winterhaven, Fla., estimates that as many as 250,000 people pick fruit in
Florida.

State officials acknowledge that their figures do not include illegal aliens or
pickers who work groves sporadically, but they say the association's figures are
exaggerated.

Because the freeze spared most groves in areas south of Orange County, thousands
of workers are expected to seek jobs in the lush, emerald groves as far South as
LaBelle in Hendry County. The increased competition has forced wages down,
migrant leaders say.

Less Money for PickingA 90-pound box of fruit that would be worth 70 cents to 80
cents in wages for picking in a good year is bringing 45 cents to 60 cents this
year, they said.

''The work is available to them if they want to move where the fruit is,'' said
Dave Gurney, general manager of the D. G. Harmon Fruit Company of Clermont.

Mr. Gurney expects to harvest 75 percent less fruit than usual in 1,200 acres of
freeze-damaged groves the company owns in Lake and Orange Counties. Harvesting
will not begin there for several weeks, he said, but harvesting has already
begun at Harmon's groves in the Fort Pierce, LaBell and Sebring areas, which
were untouched by the freeze.

''They're either going to have to learn a new trade, or they're going to have to
move,'' Mr. Phillips said.

Don Orr, manager of the State Employment Office in Sebring, has organized a
group of social service agencies to prepare for the pickers forced south by the
freeze.

Mr. Orr estimates that 3,500 workers return to the area every year and expects
that figure could triple this year.

''Our major concern is housing,'' Mr. Orr said.

Church Camps and Tents

He said there is barely enough housing for the usual number of farm workers, and
the agencies have asked church camps to provide room and the National Guard to
provide tents. The social service group is also collecting canned goods and is
trying to make employers, who may be hesitant to hire the migrants, aware of the
workers' problems.''

Mr. Orr said the group has also considered asking President Reagan to extend a
disaster declaration beyond the end of the year.

''We just feel that if we don't have some plan of action, the people will drift
around,'' Mr. Orr said.

''It wouldn't help them at all to move them from county to county,'' he added.
''They're going to have to sit out this winter season somewhere.''

Mr. Reagan declared a disaster in five Florida counties in March, which helped
provide $15.7 million in unemployment aid to 9,124 citrus workers. Workers got
an average of $41 in weekly assistance. The aid is scheduled to expire Dec. 31,
and a spokesman for the State Department of Community Affairs said there was
little chance it would be extended.

Joe Bor, 60 years old, said, while visiting in the unemployment claims office in
Winter Garden, that he has picked fruit for 26 years and does not want to
relocate. ''I'll pick fruit, that's all I know how to do,'' he said.

              January 24, 1985, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

9 PLEAD NOT GUILTY IN TUCSON TO SMUGGLING ILLEGAL ALIENS

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING

SECTION: Section A; Page 10, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 967 words

DATELINE: TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 23


While nine leaders of the American sanctuary movement pleaded not guilty in
Federal District Court here today to charges of illegally smuggling Central
Americans into this country, about 100 refugees they helped bring in gathered in
a synagogue to condemn United States policy in that part of the world.

The Central Americans, mostly from El Salvador and Guatemala, sat in a roped-off
section of the Temple Emanu-El, one of 14 houses of worship here that are part
of the sanctuary movement. They listened over headphones to a Spanish
translation of a keynote address at a two-day symposium, delivered by the Rev.
William Sloane Coffin of Riverside Church in New York City, one of about 200
churches nationally that are part of the movement.

''The real issue is human rights,'' Mr. Coffin said. ''We must continue the
sanctuary movement in its present form until Congress makes it no longer
necessary to do so.''

Nine Leaders Released

In the Federal court downtown, meanwhile, the nine leaders of the movement were
released on their own recognizance after entering their not guilty pleas to 71
counts of conspiracy to smuggle and harbor illegal aliens. The nine included the
Rev. John M. Fife, who publicly announced that his Tucson Southside Presbyterian
Church was giving sanctuary to Central Americans he and others were helping
bring into the country.

In Phoenix, four other members of sanctuary movement were arraigned on similar
charges. They were also released after pleading not guilty.

Mr. Fife said after his court appearance, ''It's our contention that the United
States Government has been breaking the law.''

The smuggling and hiding of Central Americans began secretly here in 1981, but
has continued as a matter of open policy at Mr. Fife's church since March 1982.

Other churches have joined the movement, making no secret that they help
transport, feed and provide shelter to people who say they are fleeing political
oppression, torture and death in Central America.

The great majority of the Central American aliens who have entered this country
since 1980 and then applied for political asylum have been denied it and
deported.

The Government maintains that very few are actually fleeing political
persecution, but rather severe economic hardship, which is not a legal reason
for granting asylum.

Central Americans Arrested

Although more than 60 Central American aliens were arrested and named as
unindicted co-conspirators in a Government crackdown on the sanctuary movement
10 days ago, the Federal authorities have not yet raided a church to arrest
undocumented aliens. There is no statutory prohibition against doing so.

The indictments against sanctuary movement leaders, however, resulted from a
10-month undercover operation in which Federal agents and informants infiltrated
the movement and made more than 100 secret tape recordings of meetings and
conversations in which smuggling of refugees was discussed and planned at the
Southside Church.

At Temple Emanu-El, Raquel Ovryn, one of the coordinators of the symposium, said
she did not believe the temple would be raided and the refugess arrested, but
that a number of laywers were on hand if that occurred. The symposium is to be
followed by a closed two-day meeting at which plans are to be laid to continue
aiding refugees.

At the courthouse, Mr. Fife indicated that the Government had previously
acknowledged a policy of not entering churches to arrest refugees, but added,
''We have taken steps to protect them, but I can't comment on that.''

In addition those arrainged today, three others have been indicted on charges of
conspiracy to transport illegal aliens.

However, Federal District Judge Raymond T. Terlizzi postponed their
arraignments. The reason given by the judge was that two of them were Mexican
nationals who might not be under the jurisidiction of United States law and the
third had not obtained a lawyer.

All those arraigned today were to appear in court in April.

Trial Opens in Texas

Meanwhile, the trial of another sanctuary movement worker, Jack Elder, indicted
last March on a charge of transporting three Salvadorans illegally inside this
country, began today in Federal court in Corpus Christi.

Judge Hayden Head Jr. had earlier denied motions to dismiss the case on grounds
that Mr. Elder acted out of religious conviction, that his arrest represented
selective prosecution in that others doing the same thing were not prosecuted,
and that illegal aliens were routinely transported inside the United States,
usually for agricultural purposes.

In opening testimony, a Border Patrol agent identified Mr. Elder as the man he
said he saw drop off three undocumented Salvadorans at a bus station in
Harlingen last March, then speed away as agent approached.

Mr. Elder's lawyer said today that he would use as a defense the sanctuary
movement's contention that the Central Americans they assist actually should be
admitted under the terms of the Refugee Act of 1980, and that it is the
Government that is violating the law by failing to admit them.



U.S. Action Is Defended

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI) - Alan C. Nelson, Commissioner of the Immigration and
Naturalization Service, today defended the Government's recent crackdown on the
sanctuary movement. He said the Government had not been , ''targeting'' church
groups.

Mr. Nelson, commenting on the indictments of sanctuary participants in Arizona,
asserted they had ''openly flaunted the laws.'' Mr. Nelson had approved the
indictments.

''We are not focusing on the churches,'' Mr. Nelson said in an interview. ''We
were focusing on the smuggling. We have the laws of this country to carry out
and I think it's essential to do so.''

                March 6, 1984, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

CONTRACTS FOR DETENTION RAISE LEGAL QUESTIONS

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING

SECTION: Section A; Page 10, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 919 words

DATELINE: HOUSTON, March 5


Even in Houston, where high fences are commonplace, the compound looks strangely
out of place on the edge of a residential neighborhood, just off a major
interstate highway.

The sign outside that reads ''Olympic Motel'' and under that ''Color TV, Radio,
Telephone'' seems at odds with the 12-foot cyclone fence, topped with coiled
barbed wire and laced with bamboo to thwart the curious.

Behind it young Latin men throw a Frisbee around an exercise yard that used to
be a motel courtyard.

''Day Rates Available,'' says a sign on the wall.

The odd compound is the outgrowth of what appears to be a growing trend in the
incarceration of Federal prisoners and detainees: Farming them out to private
security agencies under contract.

Holds 140 Illegal Aliens


The makeshift detention center here is an interim facility that houses about 140
illegal aliens being held pending deportation or other proceedings by the United
States Immigration and Naturalization Service.

The motel was leased by a Nashville- based private security agency, Corrections
Corporation of America, which turned it into a detention camp guarded by private
guards, its own and those hired from other private agencies.

''It's not bad for a jail,'' said Joe Beezley, a guard employed by ABM Security
Services, who sat in a straight- backed chair in the rear of the fenced- in
motel. ''But still,'' he said, glancing up at the barbed wire and smiling, ''I
think if I was here I'd try to climb that fence.''

Mr. Beezley said seven residents of the detention camp had done just that
recently, doing nothing to calm the fears of some area residents who were
already jittery about having the detention facility in the neighborhood.

Civil Liberties Issue


But beyond that consideration, this facility and others have stirred concern
among civil libertarians about the propriety of contracting with private
agencies for incarceration of prisoners. The American Civil Liberties Union in
Houston has brought a suit challenging the practice.

The motel is being used temporarily during construction of a 300-bed detention
center, nearing completion just south of Houston's Intercontinental Airport.
That detention center is being built and will be operated by Corrections
Corporation of America under contract with the immigration service, which will
pay the company $2.2 million the first year.

It will help house the swelling number of illegal aliens apprehended in the
interior of the country, many of whom are requesting asylum or who must
otherwise be held pending hearings or other actions by the immigration service.

The immigration service already has a similar detention center at Pasadena,
Calif., also operated by a private security agency under contract.  In addition,
the United States Bureau of Prisons has announced plans to enter into a contract
with a private agency to operate a minimum security Federal prison at a former
military installation at Mineral Wells, Tex.

Incident Raised Questions


Stefan Presser, an A.C.L.U. lawyer, said the trend is growing and raises
constitutional questions.

''There are instances in Arizona and New Mexico in which small towns in the
backwater are saying, 'Look, we think private business can do this cheaper than
government.' So they're hiring these private security firms who are going to
hold traffic violators, felons, whoever needs to be held.''

The suit brought by the American Civil Liberties Union here grew out of an
incident in 1981 in which 16 Columbian stowaways were held by a private security
agency here pending deportation. They attempted to escape, and after they were
recaptured, a guard's shotgun discharged, killing one man and seriously wounding
another.

In addition to payment of damages and other relief, the suit asks the Federal
District Court here to stop the practice of contracting for private
incarceration. Mr. Presser said that in addition to the incident at hand, the
suit is based on a contention that private agencies are not adequately equipped
and trained to do a humane job of incarceration, and also that a profit motive
is likely to generate cost-cutting measures not in the interest of either the
prisoner or the public.

A ruling by Judge John V. Singleton, chief judge of the Federal District Court
for the Southern District of Texas, is expected within the next two to three
weeks.

Minimum Standards Sought

Failing a ban on private contracting, Mr. Presser said the A.C.L.U. hopes for a
determination by the court insuring minimum standards.

''I don't care who's guarding them as long as they ae well-trained and insure
humane conditions,'' Mr. Presser said. ''The problem is, I don't believe there
is a company prepared to meet those requirements.''

Paul O'Neill, district director of the Immigration and Naturalization Service in
Houston, said minimum standards would be insured by contract compliance
provisions and by continuous supervision by I.N.S. personnel.

''We are going to have people on-site 24 hours a day,'' he said.

The contract with the security agency, he said, ''demands an extremely high
standard, appropriate health care, appropriate food and diet. No law-enforcement
agency can afford not to mind its p's and q's.''

Mr. O'Neill also said increasing numbers of of illegal aliens coming into the
United States, coupled with manpower shortages and high start-up costs for new
incarceration facilities, made private contracting necessary.

                 May 8, 1984, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

THE HESITANT HOUSE

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

SECTION: Section A; Page 14, Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 864 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7


Time is running out for Congressional action on a bill to curtail the flow of
illegal aliens, even as Democrats come under growing pressure to stall the
legislation.

The Speaker of the House, Thomas P.  O'Neill Jr., agreed last week to postpone
debate on the legislation until after the California Democratic primary June 5.
His action came in response to pleas from California Democrats in the House and
from Walter F. Mondale, the Presidential candidate whom Mr. O'Neill has
endorsed.

The bill, sponsored by Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, and
Representative Romano L. Mazzoli, Democrat of Kentucky, would penalize employers
who knowingly hired illegal aliens and would offer legal status to many illegal
aliens already in the country.

Twice in the last two years the Senate has passed similar bills, which were
supported by the Reagan Administration and opposed by many Hispanic Americans.

'The Last Postponement'


In announcing the latest delay Mr.  O'Neill said, ''This is definitely the last
postponement,'' and vowed that the House would devote a full week to debate on
the bill starting June 11. But anyone who has followed the tortuous course of
the legislation over the last two years knows its future is uncertain.

Mr. Mazzoli said the House would probably pass the bill if it came to a straight
up-or-down vote. And on specific amendments, he said, ''I'll go toe to toe with
anybody out there and we will win because we start with more than 100 votes in
our favor on any issue.''

But there are more than 80 proposed amendments pending before the Rules
Committee, which sets the terms of debate. Many would make profound changes in
the bill, and even minor amendments can stir hours of impassioned debate.

One full week of debate is an unusual amount for any bill and it is particularly
difficult to find such a block of time in an election year. The Congressional
calendar calls for the House to be in recess from May 25 to May 30, from July 2
to July 23 and from Aug. 13 to Sept. 5, with adjournment tentatively set for
Oct. 4.

Both Sides Critical


Mr. O'Neill has been criticized both by supporters of the bill, who say he is
killing it through delay, and opponents, who say he should not permit any floor
debate.

Roger Conner, executive director of the Federation for American Immigration
Reform, a private nonprofit group that supports immigration controls, said:

''In October the Speaker promised to bring the bill up early in 1984. In
February he let it be known the bill would come up in March. In March the
schedule was changed to April, and in April the word was that the bill would
come up in May. Clearly, the Speaker intends to go on repeating this ploy until
the legislative calendar is exhausted.''

Representative Edward R. Roybal, Democrat of California, said House leaders
''did not even give us the courtesy'' of holding hearings on his immigration
bill, which is preferred by Hispanic groups.

The bill avoids the two features of the Simpson-Mazzoli proposal that Hispanic
leaders find most objectionable: employer sanctions and the requirement for
employers to verify the identity of all job applicants as either citizens or
legal aliens. The Roybal bill seeks to control illegal immigration by stronger
enforcement of labor laws on the theory that employers hire illegal aliens
because they can be exploited.

Blame for Democrats


''If the Simpson-Mazzoli bill passes,'' Mr. Roybal said, ''Hispanics would blame
the Democrats, since the House is controlled by Democrats.''

Mr. Roybal's family has been in the United States since 1610, when his Spanish
ancestors settled in Santa Fe, N.M. But the Hispanic population, which sees
itself as the group most affected by the Simpson-Mazzoli bill, includes many
more recent arrivals.

According to the Census Bureau, the number of Hispanic people in the United
States grew to 14.6 million in 1980 from 9 million in 1970, and the bureau
estimates that the total reached 15.9 million in March 1983. Those of Mexican
origin grew 93 percent, to 8.7 million in 1980 from 4.5 million in 1970,
according to the bureau.

The delays in Congress do not necessarily indicate a breakdown of the
legislative process, according to lawmakers and lobbyists following the issue.
The chaos in the House, they said, represents all too well the variety and
intensity of feeling on the issue in the country at large.

Public Support Is Cited


The sponsors of the Simpson-Mazzoli bill say that numerous opinion polls have
demonstrated public support for the legislation. But such polls generally do not
measure the intensity and depth of feeling. Many members of the fast- growing
Hispanic minority, which is concentrated in several states with large numbers of
electoral votes, care passionately.

But it is not only Hispanic Americans who have been trying to defeat the bill.
Growers of fruit and vegetables who have come to depend on foreign labor oppose
the bill in its present form. They want it amended to include a temporary guest
worker program. That would be anathema to many labor unions.

REPORTER IS ARRESTED WITH FIVE IN TEXAS IN AIDING OF ALIENS

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 39, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 324 words

DATELINE: McALLEN, Tex., Feb. 18


A reporter for The Dallas Times Herald was arrested Friday with three
Salvadorans, a nun and a social worker and charged with transporting illegal
aliens.  An editor for the newspaper said said he was working on an assignment
at the time,

The arrests by officers of the United States Border Patrol came at a traffic
stop on a rural highway in south Texas. The arrests of the Catholic nun and the
social worker were among the first involving members of church groups that
announced publicly last year their intention to aid people fleeing El Salvador,
The Times Herald said.

The reporter, Jack Fischer, 30 years old, and Sister Dianne M. Muhlenkamp, 36,
of Donaldson, Ind., and the lay worker, Stacy Lynn Merkt, 29, of Colorado
Springs, were arraigned before United States Magistrate Sue Williams in McAllen.
They were freed on $10,000 personal recognizance bonds.

'Reporter on Assignment'


Larry Tarleton, managing editor of The Times Herald, said Friday that Mr.
Fischer ''was working as a reporter on assignment for The Dallas Times Herald
and was in pursuit of legitimate journalistic activities as an observer when he
was arrested.''

The Times Herald said the nun and lay worker had been serving as temporary
volunteers with Casa Romero, a nonprofit haven for Central American refugees in
San Benito.

James L. Selbe, sector chief of the Border Patrol in McAllen, said the three
were charged with transportation of illegal aliens and conspiracy to transport
illegal aliens ''based on information the Salvadorans gave during our interviews
with them.''

No charges were filed immediately against the Salvadorans. ''They are being held
as material witnesses, and they probably will be charged with being illegal
aliens,'' Mr. Selbe said.

The Salvadorans were identified as Mauricio Valle and Brenda Elizabeth
Sanchez-Galan, both said to be in their 20's, and Mrs. Sanchez-Galan's 1-year-
old daughter, Bessie.

                April 30, 1984, Monday, Late City Final Edition

4 DIE WHEN TRAIN TRAPS ILLEGAL ALIENS ON TRESTLE

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 11, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 527 words

DATELINE: KINGSVILLE, Tex., April 29


A freight train plowed through a group of illegal aliens walking across a
railroad trestle in the dark Saturday night, forcing some to jump into a shallow
creek 31 feet below. Four were killed and at least seven were injured.

As many as 40 people may have been on the bridge when the train approached at
about 40 miles an hour, said Rod Saucier, agent in charge of the United States
Border Patrol office in Kingsville.

Tim Hogan, a Missouri Pacific Railroad spokesman in Chicago, said the train
engineer saw the people on the bridge but was unable to stop the 43-car train
until it had crossed the 464-foot trestle over Olmos Creek, 17 miles south of
Kingsville and about 85 miles north of the Mexican border.

The dead were two women, a boy about 12 years old and a younger child, a Border
Patrol official said.

Some Said to Be Hiding


Immediately after the accident, the authorities arrested 14 people who escaped
injury. Today, in a search for more victims in the three- to four-foot-deep
creek and for survivors who may have sought cover in the mesquite that dots the
rugged coastal area south of Corpus Christi, the authorities found 20 people,
none of whom admitted knowing anything of the accident.

''There's probably 300, 400 who cross here every day in little groups like
these,'' said Joe Mays, a Kleberg County sheriff's deputy.

The aliens were walking north on the trestle when they were surprised about
10:10 P.M. by the train traveling south from Kingsville to Harlingen, Mr.
Saucier said.

As the train approached, some of the people jumped from the bridge, some tried
to outrun the train and some tried to avoid the locomotive by standing at the
edge of the trestle, he said. Because of the brush and a curve in the tracks
north of the bridge they may not have seen the train until it was quite close to
the trestle, he said.

Most From El Salvador


Some of the 14 uninjured who were arrested after the accident were taken to the
Kenedy County Sheriff's office at Sarita, from which they were to be sent to a
detention center, Mr. Saucier said.

Some of them would be given documents allowing them to stay with injured
relatives at hospitals, he added.

The authorities thought most of the people were in this country illegally from
El Salvador, Mr. Saucier said, and some were from Mexico. Most of them probably
either paid or agreed to pay smugglers $500 to $600 apiece to be brought into
the country, he said.

Five of the injured were taken to Memorial Hospital in nearby Corpus Christi and
two were taken to Kleberg Hospital in Kingsville.

A spokesman at Memorial Hospital said four people were in critical condition in
the intensive care unit and a fifth person was in stable condition. The
patients, four children and a woman, all suffered multiple injuries, said a
hospital spokesman, John Gilliam.

A spokesman for Kleberg Hospital said two patients were in intensive care and an
uninjured child was admitted to the pediatric unit for shelter. The hospital
declined to give details, but the railroad spokesman, Mr. Hogan, said he was
told the two patients were in fair condition.

AROUND THE NATION;
Alien Deaths FollowedLong March in Texas

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 16, Column 6; National Desk

DATELINE: KINGSVILLE, Tex., May 1


Illegal aliens forced to jump from a trestle because of a freight train had been
led by smugglers on a forced march for 18 to 20 hours without food or water, a
United States Border Patrol officer said today.

Four aliens were killed and seven were injured seriously Saturday night when a
Missouri Pacific train surprised the group as they walked across a long, narrow
trestle.

Survivors said three smugglers had allowed the group of 47 predominantly
Salvadoran aliens to stop only once in a 24-hour period, said Bob Gilbert, the
assistant chief Border Patrol agent in McAllen.

''They said they stopped once and slept for six hours under some bushes,'' Chief
Gilbert said today. ''But they didn't get any food or water. The men said there
would be food when they reached the vehicles.''

COMMENCEMENT DAY: A TIME OF GOODBYES AND ANTICIPATION;
KOCH ASSERTS PUBLIC SERVICE CAN BE 'NOBLEST OF PROFESSIONS'

SECTION: Section B; Page 8, Column 3; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 415 words


Mayor Koch played campus recruiter yesterday and urged the 1,100 graduates of
Manhattan College to consider careers in public service.

''It's truly the noblest of professions when done honorably and well,'' the
Mayor said in the keynote address at the institution's 133d commencement, in the
Draddy Gymnasium in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

''We are the trustees of this extraordinary city and we have an obligation to
deliver the city to the next generation in better shape,'' Mr. Koch said.

Problem of Illegal Aliens


As an example of the trials and rewards of public service, Mr. Koch cited the
need to provide services for the city's illegal aliens, who he said totaled more
than half a million.

The Mayor urged the Federal Government to improve its patrolling of the nation's
borders and to shoulder a greater part of the fiscal burden for educational and
medical services to illegal aliens.

Despite the job's many headaches, Mr. Koch told the graduates, ''I enjoy being
the Mayor of the City of New York.''

Mr. Koch received an honorary Doctor of Humane Letters degree for ''nursing the
city's budget back to health'' and for other contributions to New York City.

A Busy Day for Mayor


The Mayor arrived huffing and puffing and a bit late, having already attended
three parades. Nevertheless, the audience greeted him warmly, whistling and
chanting. ''Eddie, Eddie,'' whereupon he struck his familiar pose, with both
arms outstretched.

The Mayor also said he would make copies of his speech available after the
event, ''for one dollar plus postage.''

Some of the graduates said that while they did not have jobs waiting for them,
they had no regrets about graduating other than that they were limited to four
tickets each for the ceremony.

''It's easier getting Lionel Richie tickets,'' said Robert Costa, a senior of
Fort Lee, N.J., who, like many of his classmates, had more aunts and uncles than
tickets.

The college awarded these other honorary degrees: REV. DR. JAMES R. CRUMLEY,
Jr.,

Bishop of the Lutheran Church in America; Doctor of Humane Letters, for his

work ''toward the better understanding

between Lutherans and Roman Catholics.'' REV. JOSEPH P. FITZPATRICK, S.J.,

professor emeritus of sociology at Fordham Univeristy; Doctor of Humane Letters,
for ''introducing the social sciences

into the curriculum of many Catholic

Colleges in the late 1940's and 1950's''

and for his many articles on sociology.

                 June 3, 1984, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

CONSERVATIVE HOLDS LEAD IN TEXAS SENATE PRIMARY

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 33, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 643 words

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., June 2


Representative Kent Hance, a folksy West Texas conservative Democrat who
co-sponsored President Reagan's tax package, held a slim lead for the Democratic
nomination to the Senate in a runoff primary in Texas tonight, but the outcome
remained in doubt.

Mr. Hance's runoff campaign centered on opposition to proposals to grant amnesty
to illegal aliens already in the country and charges that his opponent, State
Senator Lloyd Doggett, waged a ''mudslinging'' attack on his voting record on
Social Security matters.

Although Mr. Hance led Mr. Doggett with over 90 percent of the vote counted,
precinct analysts in both camps said the outcome was too close to call because
much of the early vote tabulated was from rural precincts that voted heavily for
Mr. Hance.

The Vote Tally


With 94 percent of 6,063 precincts counted, Mr. Hance had 444,870 votes, or 51.3
percent, and Mr. Doggett had 422,995 votes, or 48.7 percent.

The winner will face the Republican candidate, Representative Phil Gramm, for
the seat being vacated by Senator John Tower, a Republican.

The contest for the Democratic nomination was bitterly fought from the
beginning.  In the first primary campaign, Robert Krueger, the former
Representative who came within one percentage point of defeating Mr. Tower six
years ago, was considered the front-runner. Mr. Doggett had been expected to run
second and Mr. Hance third.

Instead, the race ended in almost a dead heat, and it was three days before the
surprising first returns, with some modification, were confirmed.

Narrow Margin for Candidates


Instead of last, Mr. Hance ran first; Mr. Doggett, as expected, ran second, but
Mr. Krueger was third, and out of the running. Once again, Mr. Krueger lost by a
thin margin, this time by less than a tenth of a percentage point. He finished
behind Mr. Doggett by 1,287 votes out of nearly 1.5 million cast.

Mr. Hance's upset victory was attributed to a blitz of television advertising in
the closing two weeks of the campaign in which he denounced proposals to grant
amnesty to some illegal aliens in this country, an emotional issue in Texas,
which shares a 1,200-mile border with Mexico.

But a key factor was also Mr. Doggett's relentless assault on Mr. Krueger's
record as a member of Congress, particularly what Mr. Doggett said was a poor
attendance record.

With Mr. Krueger out of the race, Mr. Doggett turned his research staff loose on
Mr. Hance, who has served two terms in the House.

The researchers came up with votes by Mr. Hance against increases in Social
Security, and Mr. Doggett's Los Angeles media adviser, Bill Zimmerman, using
actors, produced a scathing television commercial.

Mr. Hance responded with his own television campaign, with the result that the
monthlong runoff campaign was largely a battle of media imagery.

Hance Savaged in Ads


In one Doggett spot, Mr. Hance was portrayed saying he would ''fight against
cuts in Social Security.''

An elderly man snaps, ''That's a durn lie.''

Another senior citizen says, ''You can't trust that Hance fellow on Social
Security,'' and another adds, ''Or anything else.''

Mr. Doggett also savaged Mr. Hance for his sponsorship of the Reagan tax cut
package with a commercial portraying Mr. Hance as a butler serving on a silver
platter a volume entitled ''Tax Breaks for the Rich.'' The wealthy master
haughtily intoned: ''Very good, Hance.''

Mr. Hance responded with commercials of his own that showed mud splattering
against the screen and the tagline, ''Lloyd Doggett is mudslinging again.''

The ads said Mr. Hance never voted to cut Social Security and that the tax cuts
he co-sponsored treated everyone equally.

It concluded that ''Hance is against amnesty for illegal aliens; Doggett is for
it, and no amount of muslinging can cover that up.''

                 June 4, 1984, Monday, Late City Final Edition

SHELTERING OF SALVADORANS IS DEBATED

BYLINE: By ARI L. GOLDMAN

SECTION: Section B; Page 3, Column 4; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 995 words


The congregation of the Riverside Church debated yesterday whether to provide
shelter for a family of illegal aliens from El Salvador, a move that would put
the church in conflict with the United States Government and with its own boards
of trustees and deacons.

In a crowded basement meeting room after the Sunday service, 250 church members
discussed whether Riverside should join 110 churches around the country that
have declared themselves sanctuaries for refugees fleeing violence in Central
America.

''I feel it is our Christian duty to help these people,'' said Christine Carter,
a member of the congregation who favors opening up the church to the refugees.

''It is a dishonest, political proposal,'' said another member, William Peck.

Financial Burden


For nearly two hours, members asked questions. What legal risks would the church
be taking? What would be the financial burden? Would providing protection be
seen as a political statement or a humanitarian gesture? And, should the church
first take care of poor people in New York before extending a helping hand to
the oppressed of Central America?

Advocates said American churches had a responsibility to shelter the Salvadoran
refugees. They charged that the United States Government had refused to grant
them asylum because to do so would be to concede that it was supporting an
''oppressive'' government in El Salvador. There is a historic precedent, they
added, for using churches as sanctuaries that dates to biblical times.

Church members heard from legal experts and from sanctuary church workers in
other cities, including Brother Philip, a Benedictine monk from a monastery in
Weston, Vt., that took in a family of seven Guatemalan refugees in April.

Whatever the religious, legal or political considerations, Brother Philip said,
the experience of taking in refugees was in itself enriching. ''We are very much
on the receiving end,'' he said. ''They bring an outlook on faith and on the
Gospel that we could not gain otherwise.''

Deeply Divided on Issue


The Riverside Church, which was built in 1929 by the Rockefeller family at 122d
Street and Riverside Drive, is deeply divided on the sanctuary issue. The senior
minister, Rev. William Sloane Coffin, has preached in favor of the move. The
board of trustees and the board of deacons have voted against it.

The 2,500 members of Riverside will have an opportunity to vote on the issue at
a special meeting following the church service next Sunday.

If the membership of the interdenominational church approves the proposal by a
vote of at least two-thirds of those present next week, the board of trustees
has agreed to reconsider the issue, according to a spokesman for the trustees,
Cheryl Parham. The board of deacons, she added, would be bound by the decision
of the congregation and the trustees.

A Practical Matter


At yesterday's meeting, Emily Ellis, a Riverside member for 50 years, asked
about practical matters. ''Who will feed them,'' she wondered.

Mary Ann Lundy, a member of the church's sanctuary committee, said the refugees
would be housed and fed in the church, at an annual cost of about $5,000 per
person. Churches usually take in a family, but the specific refugees for
Riverside will not be determined until after a final decision on sanctuary is
made.

Another longtime member of the church, Ramsey McGregor, said he understood that
''emotional and religious'' issues were involved, but added that ''I find it
difficult to say that Riverside Church should break the law.''

In recent statements, officials of the United States Immigration and
Naturalization Service have put church leaders on notice that they were liable
to fines of up to $2,000 and five years in prison for sheltering illegal aliens.

''A church cannot harbor illegal aliens any more than it can hide criminals,''
Duke Austin, a spokesman for the Immigration Service, said in a recent
interview.

Two Arrests Made


In recent months, at least two sanctuary church workers have been arrested for
transporting illegal aliens, one in Texas and one in Arizona, although no
arrests on church property have been made.

Robert Potter, a lawyer who is advising Riverside's sanctuary committee,
predicted that the current interpretation of the immigration laws by the Reagan
Administration would be overturned by the courts. He said those arrested were
protected by international agreements that offered protection for those fleeing
foreign oppression.

Mr. Potter added that he did not expect the Administration would try to
prosecute church members who were active in providing sanctuary, although he
said the Government might try to deny churches tax-exempt status for engaging in
such activity.

'Our Own Backyard'


Among church members who expressed opposition to the move was a church deacon,
Joyce Perry-Jacobs. ''This church does not seem to get involved in social issues
affecting people right in this neighborhood,'' she said. ''I challenge Riverside
to think about the hundreds of people in our own backyard - in Harlem.''

Advocates of the sanctuary proposal argue that Riverside operates a shelter for
the homeless that provides beds for 10 men every night and a free lunch program
for about 50 poor persons daily. But Mrs. Perry-Jacobs said that those measures
were ''Band-Aids'' and that much more remained to be done in the neighborhood.

Jack Elder, a church worker from Texas who was arrested for transporting illegal
aliens, said the political and humanitarian concerns were linked. ''We as a
country, through our tax dollars, are sponsors of official terrorism in El
Salvador,'' he told the audience. ''We have a special duty to our victims.''

He said his Roman Catholic organization, Casa Romero, in Brownsville, Tex., near
the Mexican border, had helped 1,200 Salvadoran refugees resettle in the United
States in the last year.
