               February 22, 1985, Friday, Late City Final Edition

FIRST GROUP OF CUBAN ALIENS SENT BACK AS UNDESIRABLES

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT

SECTION: Section A; Page 10, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 944 words

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Feb. 21


Twenty-three Cuban aliens were put aboard an airplane here today bound for
Havana, the first of more than 2,700 unwanted Cubans who could be sent back as
part of an agreement with the Government of Fidel Castro.

Their transfer marked the first step in a diplomatic accord between Washington
and Havana in which Cuba has agreed to the return of 2,746 refugees from the
1980 boatlift from the fishing port of Mariel. The Cubans being deported are
being held as undesirables in American jails and mental hospitals.

In return for Havana's accepting the Cubans, the United States has promised to
allow about 20,000 Cubans to immigrate to the United States each year.

Subject to Deportation

United States immigration officials said the 23 men in today's group, like most
others in Federal custody, had committed serious crimes either in Cuba or the
United States and were therefore subject to deportation because they were
legally ineligible for residence in this country.

The men were put aboard a chartered Boeing 727 at Dobbins Air Force Base
northwest of here after being transferred by bus from the nearby Atlanta Federal
Pentitinary. About 1,750 of the 2,746 refugees awaiting transfer to Cuba are in
the Atlanta prison.

While armed guards looked on, the Cubans, dressed in blue prison overalls and
wearing wrist manacles, boarded the airplane, parked more than 700 yards from
the nearest building.

They were to be accompanied on the two-hour flight to Cuba by nearly 30 guards
and other officials of the Immigration and Naturalization Service and the Bureau
of Prisons. A spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration here said the
plane landed in Havana, according to The Associated Press.

An official with the immigration service here said that with the exception of
the return in 1981 of a stowaway who had illegally entered the United States,
the 23 were the first Cuban nationals to be officially sent back under the
agreement reached Dec. 14 between the United States and Cuba. That was the first
formal accord between the two governments since the Reagan Administration took
office in 1981.

Earlier in the day, the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit here
cleared the way for the deportation of 16 members of the group when it
overturned an order from a Federal district judge, who on Tuesday forbade the
Government from deporting them because of what he called unresolved legal
issues.

16 Had Fought Deportation

The 16 men had contested their deportation. The other seven men had not objected
to being deported, Government officials said.

Judge Charles A. Moye Jr. said the Government had shown ''unseemly haste'' to
return the Cubans.

The Justice Department filed an emergency appeal Wednesday, saying that the
court order threatened to disrupt arrangements agreed to by Cuba. In earlier
court appearances, Justice Department lawyers had argued that if the refugees
were not returned soon, the Cuban Government might change its mind about
accepting them.

The transfer today was a setback for the the refugees who do not want to return
to Cuba. Their lawyers say they will continue efforts try to block further
deportation proceedings because of pending claims for political asylum.

The lawyers argue that the aliens might be subject to persecution and even
torture on their return to Cuba, despite promises by the Castro Government that
they would be treated fairly.

''If all the evidence were considered and a careful analysis of their crimes
undertaken, not all of those returned today would be found ineligible for
asylum,'' said Deborah Ebel, an attorney who has been working on behalf of the
refugees for four years. ''I think the shame is that we might never know what
will happen to them.''

Miss Ebel noted that a hearing was scheduled next week before the 11th circuit
appeals court on whether all the Cuban aliens in the Atlanta prison are
entitled, as a group, to new hearings by immigration officials on their claims
for asylum.

The 2,746 refugees the Government wants to send back came in the so- called
Freedom Flotilla, a makeshift armada of small boats that brought more than
125,000 Cubans to Florida. The vast majority of those refugees have managed to
successfully integrate themselves into American society. They became eligible
last December to apply for permanent resident status.

As a result of the boatlift, the United States suspended emigration from Cuba.
There were reports that Mr. Castro put criminals and mental patients aboard the
boats. Mr. Castro denied the allegations.



Political Prisoners Accepted

Among the group returned today were men who had admitted to homicide, burglary
and assaults while in Cuba. Federal prison officials have said that about 400 of
the 1,750 inmates at the Atlanta penitentiary had been there since they arrived
in the United States in 1980.

Under terms of the agreement with Cuba, the Unites States will return up to 100
of the Cubans a month. In addition to allowing 20,000 Cuban immigrants a year,
the United States has promised to accept about 3,000 Cuban political prisoners
and their families.

Duke Austin, a spokesman for the immigration service in Atlanta, said 1,400 of
the 2,746 Cubans covered by the accord had received final orders of exclusion,
which means they are subject to immediate deportation. But he says immigration
officials are now individually reviewing the cases of those who have recently
made application for political asylum.

The continuing incarceration of the Cuban aliens has cost the Federal Government
about $41 million a year, immigration officials said today.

               February 25, 1985, Monday, Late City Final Edition

U.S. FAULTED ON CUBAN ALIENS

SECTION: Section A; Page 11, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 315 words


Nearly two thousand Cuban refugees held in state prisons throughout the country
were omitted from a list of aliens scheduled to be deported to Cuba, Senator
Alfonse M. D'Amato said yesterday.

The New York Republican, in a statement critical of the the Immigration and
Naturalization Service, said the service had failed to list the state prisoners
among 2,746 refugees who have been declared undesirables and are now held in
mental hospitals and Federal prisons.

Those refugees are being sent back to Cuba as part of an agreement with the
Government of Fidel Castro. Twenty- three Cubans, who were among more than 1,700
being held at the Federal Penitentiary in Atlanta, were flown to Havana Thursday
as the deportation began.

The refugees, part of the 1980 boatlift from the Cuban fishing port of Mariel,
committed serious crimes either in Cuba or the United States. The ones being
held in state prisons fall into the same categories, an aide to the Senator
said.

Among the states where the aliens are being held are Pennsylvania, New Jersey
and Florida, Mr. D'Amato said. He said the confinement of these prisoners was
costing states an estimated $40 million annually. In New York State facilities,
he said, only 19 out of 360 inmates had been scheduled for deportation.

''This is the fault of the Immigration and Naturalization Service,'' the Senator
said. ''They've done a terrible job. I think it's a case where the Immigration
and Naturalization Service just didn't give the kind of care and attention thay
they should have to this situation.''

Verne Jervis, a spokeman for the immigration service, would not comment on Mr.
D'Amato's charges.

Under the terms of the Dec. 14 agreement with Cuba, the refugees would be
returned at a rate of 100 a month. In exchange, the United States has promised
to allow the resumption of normal immigration policy with Cuba.

                  May 7, 1984, Monday, Late City Final Edition

HISPANIC SUPPORT FOR EMPLOYER SANCTIONS

SECTION: Section A; Page 18, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 280 words


To the Editor:


Recent reports in The Times portray divisions within the Democratic Party
between Hispanic-Americans and organized labor on the desirability of a law
making it illegal for employers to hire illegal aliens. These reports seem to
suggest that there is a consensus among Hispanics that employer sanctions are
undesirable because of their potential to cause discrimination against
minorities.

In fact, the opposite is true. In 1983, two polls confirmed that
Hispanic-Americans favor employer sanctions. In October 1983, a Gallup Poll
found that 75 percent of Hispanic respondents favored a bill making it ''against
the law to employ a person without proper papers.'' Also, 75 percent of Hispanic
respondents said they thought ''everyone in the United States should be required
to carry an identification card such as a Social Security card.'' In August
1983, a poll conducted jointly by Peter D. Hart Research Associates and V. Lance
Tarrance and Associates, two of the premier political polling firms in the
country, found that 66 percent of U.S. citizens of Hispanic origin who responded
favored ''having penalties and fines for employers who hire illegal aliens.''
(Among all Hispanic respondents, 60 percent favored them.) Despite comments from
a few professional ''pols,'' it is obvious that the vast majority of
Hispanic-Americans are not going to base their Presidential votes on whether the
Democratic Party brings this bill up for a full House vote. There is a consensus
in the land. The House should get on with it.

ROGER CONNER Executive Director, Federation for American Immigration Reform
Washington, April 23, 1984

BEYOND PASSPORTS

To the Editor:


In his Aug. 27 Op-Ed article, ''U.S. Wealth, Not Foreign Poverty, Comes First,''
Jack Beatty deplores the loss of U.S. jobs to cheap foreign labor. While this is
certainly lamentable for the American worker and the American economy, far more

place the name of the country on your passport before humankind.

MARK OLMSTED New York, Aug. 27, 1984

               December 4, 1984, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

SUPREME COURT ROUNDUP;
'EXCLUDABLE' HAITIANS TO GET HEARING ON PLEA

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE

SECTION: Section A; Page 18, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1039 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3


The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether Haitian refugees seeking asylum
in the United States could challenge the constitutionality of their confinement
in Federal detention centers.

The case could produce an important ruling on the rights of a particular group
of aliens, those who have never entered the country but have been stopped at the
border and are deemed ''excludable.''

A Federal appeals court ruled earlier this year, in a lawsuit brought in behalf
of 2,000 Haitian ''boat people,'' that excludable aliens ''have no
constitutional rights'' to challenge the way in which their admission to the
country is handled.

By a vote of 8 to 4 that court, the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th
Circuit, overturned an earlier ruling by a panel of three of its judges that the
Government's policy of keeping the Haitians in detention while considering their
asylum applications amounted to unconstitutional discrimination on the basis of
national origin.

Dred Scott Decision Cited

The Haitians' appeal to the Supreme Court argued that not since the Dred Scott
decision of 1857, in which the Court ruled that blacks born into slavery had no
constitutional rights, had a Federal court ruled that ''a class of persons is
wholly beyond the Constitution.''

The Haitians' appeal was supported by the N.A.A.C.P., the Congressional Black
Caucus and several other civil rights organizations.

The Court's decision to hear the appeal was something of a surprise. The Justice
Department had urged the Court not to take the case, telling the Justices that
the 11th Circuit's constitutional view was ''fully consistent with a long line
of precedent.'' Three years ago, in another immigration case, the Supreme Court
ruled that an alien seeking initial admission to the country ''requests a
privilege'' and has ''no constitutional rights regarding his application.''

Other Decisions on Aliens

By contrast, the courts have interpreted the Constitution as providing an array
of protections for aliens who have managed to enter the country, even if their
entry was illegal. The Supreme Court ruled several years ago that Texas could
not deny a free public education to illegal alien children. The Haitian appeal,
Jean v. Nelson, No. 84- 5240, involves only the narrower category of aliens who
are deemed, in effect, never to have entered the country in the first place.

Relatively few of the Haitians involved in the case are still in detention. Most
were released in 1982 as a result of a Federal District Court decision that the
Reagan Administration had not followed proper procedures in 1981 when it adopted
a new policy of detaining aliens whose asylum claims had not yet been
determined. The previous policy had been a liberal use of parole for aliens
whose status as refugees was not yet settled. The Administration recodified its
new policy to conform to the court's procedural requirements, and the Haitians
renewed their constitutional argument that the detention policy was
unconstitutional.

The scope of the Court's eventual decision, which is expected by early next
summer, is somewhat unclear. If the Court decides that the 11th Circuit was
wrong, and that excludable aliens may raise a constitutional challenge to their
treatment, the normal course would be for the Court to send the case back to the
lower courts for a ruling on whether the detention policy violated the
Constitution. But it is at least theoretically possible that the Supreme Court
itself could choose to address the merits of the constitutional case.

The Court also agreed today to hear another immigration case, this time at the
request of the Federal Government. The immigration laws permit the Attorney
General to suspend deportation proceedings against an otherwise deportable alien
who has been ''physically present in the United States'' for a continuous period
of seven years and who can show that deportation would be an ''extreme
hardship.''

The question in the case the Court accepted today is whether the Attorney
General may refuse to grant a hearing to an alien who reached the seven-year
mark only through the filing of frivolous appeals that have enabled him to
escape deportation. The United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit
ruled, in the case of a husband and wife who entered the country illegally from
Mexico in 1974, that the filing of numerous appeals did not justify the
Government's refusal to grant a new hearing. The Government appealed on the
ground that the decision would encourage ''dilatory tactics'' and disregard of
the immigration laws. (I.N.S. v. Rios- Pineda, No. 83-2032).

Other developments today included:

Military Access

Accepting another Government appeal, the Court agreed to decide whether someone
who had been formally barred from entering a military base may also be kept off
the base at an ''open house'' to which the public at large is invited.

The case, U.S. v. Albertini, No. 83- 1624, involves a ''bar letter'' procedure,
which prevents entry to a particular base without permission. Ignoring a bar
letter is a criminal offense punishable by fine or jail.

The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled that the First
Amendment's free speech guarantee prevented the Government from enforcing the
law against a recipient of a bar letter who re-entered the base for an open
house to engage in an antiwar demonstration. The case grew out of an incident at
Hickam Air Force Base in Hawaii.

 Handicapped Children

The Court agreed to examine the circumstances under which local school districts
may be required by Federal law to reimburse the parents of handicapped children
for private school tuition. The case involves a learning-disabled child whose
parents took him out of the Burlington, Mass., public schools in a dispute over
whether the district could design an appropriate program for him. The school
district is appealing a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the
First Circuit that the parents' action did not necessarily free the district of
the obligation to reimburse them. The case, School Committee v. Mass. Dept. of
Education, No. 84- 433, arose under the Education of the Handicapped Act.
